headline.main: Must Self-Funded Plans Comply With the New Law?

docs.abstract: Self-funded insurance plans will be subject to most of the rules governing large group plans.
docs.snippet: Self-funded insurance plans will be subject to most of the rules governing large group plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's easy to look at the protesters and the politicians in Greece -- and at the other European countries with huge debts -- and wonder why they don't get it. They have been enjoying more generous government benefits than they can afford. No mass rally and no bailout fund will change that. Only benefit cuts or tax increases can.

headline.main: In Greek Crisis, Some See Parallels to U.S. Debt

docs.abstract: The United States will probably not face the same kind of crisis as Greece, for all sorts of reasons. But the basic problem is the same. Both countries have a bigger government than they're paying for.
docs.snippet: The United States will probably not face the same kind of crisis as Greece, for all sorts of reasons. But the basic problem is the same. Both countries have a bigger government than they're paying for.

docs.lead_paragraph: PRYSTOWSKY--Milton, MD passed away unexpectedly on May 10, 2010. Milt was born in Charleston, South Carolina on February 17, 1922. He was the beloved husband of the late Rose Prystowsky, MD. and is survived by his loving children, Doctors Stephen, Eric, Michael, Barry, and Richard, devoted daughters-in-law, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and brother, Sidney, MD. After training in pediatrics and pediatric cardiology at the Harriet Lane Home of Johns Hopkins University under the tutelage of Helen Taussig, Milt was the first pediatric cardiologist in New Jersey and opened the Division of Pediatric Cardiology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. In his signature bow tie, he practiced as a pediatrician and pediatric cardiologist in Nutley, NJ from 1951 to 2004. Even in retirement, he continued to see patients as a consultant at Children's Hospital of New Jersey. His many years of service as a tireless healer of and advocate for children--especially those who are most vulnerable--as well as his longtime service on public health committees in New Jersey, led to improved health care and insurance benefits for children. In his more than 60 years of medical service, he had numerous accomplishments and received many awards. He was on the Founding Board of Children's Hospital (in Newark, NJ), for example. He served as President of the Public Health Council of New Jersey, which oversees the New Jersey State Department of Health. United Hospital of New Jersey recognized him with a special title, given only to him: "Role Model for Pediatric Residents." The New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry presented him with a Lifetime Dean's Award. He was also Clinical Professor of Pediatrics and Pediatric Cardiology at the medical schools. And, to take but one more example, he was with the national organization of all NACRI organizations (with Children's Hospital), representing New Jersey in Washington, DC, to lobby for much needed funds. Milt's seemingly indefatigable advocacy for children is perhaps best exemplified by his having led the years-long effort to establish New Jersey's Catastrophic Children's Illness Fund--a unique model in the nation, which ensures that no family in New Jersey ever has to go bankrupt because they have a child in desperate need of catastrophic medical care. This accomplishment underscores that, first and foremost, Milt was a model humanitarian, who cared about helping persons regardless of their ability to pay, and regardless of their social station in life. Indeed, what those who knew him say that they remember most about Milt was his genuine kindness, his warmth, his caring personality. No problem was ever too small to be brought to his attention, as the many persons whose lives he touched knew it. Dr. Milton Prystowsky influenced the lives of thousands of countless lives and made a significant impact on the quality of families and communities. He will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, May 12, 10am at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel, 575 King St., Port Chester, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Dr. Prystowsky's honor should be made to the Drs. Milton and Rose Medical Student Award at the Foundation, The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, 65 Bergen Street, Newark, NJ 07107.

docs.lead_paragraph: In my post yesterday on the role that the Wyden-Bennett health care bill played in Bob Bennett's primary defeat, I linked to Michael Cannon's free-market critique of the Paul Ryan/Tom Coburn proposal, which shared some features with Wyden-Bennett without inspiring any anti-Ryan or anti-Coburn backlash on the right. Ramesh Ponnuru points out that Cannon subsequently corrected and revised that critique. I regret missing that revision, not least because Cannon's apparent misapprehensions about the Ryan-Coburn bill were similar to mine.
docs.abstract: More on health care alternatives and Bob Bennett's unhappy fate.
docs.snippet: More on health care alternatives and Bob Bennett's unhappy fate.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

docs.lead_paragraph: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)
docs.abstract: Here's the latest of my increasingly desperate pleas to stem the flood of colloquialisms in news stories.Stodginess is not the goal. But we take the news seriously, and our news report should sound serious - not like teenage slang, TV happy-talk or Twitter chatter.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a letter to leaders of Congress, the secretary of health and human services, Kathleen Sebelius, reported on Monday that the Obama administration is moving quickly to carry out the expansive new health care law, particularly provisions that she referred to as "early insurance market reforms."

headline.main: Sebelius Trumpets Health Law's Immediate Impact

docs.abstract: Fending off Republican criticism the Obama administration suggests the new health care law is already helping Americans.
docs.snippet: Fending off Republican criticism the Obama administration suggests the new health care law is already helping Americans.
